citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee has changed the vaccination and deworming schedule for adults and puppies without consulting their
attending veterinarian. The licensee states they no longer vaccinate for Hepatitis and Bordatella in adult dogs or vaccinate
puppies at 5 and 7 weeks of age with Neopar and Bronchicine. French bulldog/Pug puppy born 20-May-2023 did not
receive the Panacur 3 day course at 7 weeks of age or the Nobivac 1 DAPPV vaccine at 8 weeks of age.
A French Bulldog born 13-December-2022 has not had its initial rabies vaccine at 12 weeks old per the vaccine schedule
listed in the Program of Veterinary Care. No appointment has been made at the time of inspection.
The licensee has not communicated with the attending veterinarian about a French/English Bulldog cross puppy
(Diamond's litter born 2-July-2023) that has an abnormal eye condition that was noticed at least 2 days prior. A small red
growth is located in the interior corner of the left eye and is covering approximately a quarter of the surface of the eye.
Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care vaccination and deworming schedules approved by the attending
veterinarian does not ensure the animals are protected against contagious and/or deadly diseases. Delay in contacting a
veterinarian regarding the changing health of the animals does not ensure adequate veterinary care is being provided to
diagnose and treat medical conditions.
Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee
must ensure that all dogs presenting abnormal conditions are evaluated and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that all
vaccinations and deworming plans are approved by the attending veterinarian and followed in order to provide the dogs
with adequate veterinary care.

Seven adult dogs do not have official identification placed on the dog. The licensee uses microchips placed under the skin
as a form of official identification. The following dogs need a microchip: Gisella, Merlitta, Josie, Maggie, Moxie, Borris and
French Bulldog born 13-December-2022. The French Bulldog is still being identified by its puppy cage card. Cage cards
are not an acceptable form of official identification for dogs over 16 weeks of age. An acceptable form of official
identification (listed below) is necessary for APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly
trace their movements.
All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin. The licensee must
apply one of the forms of identification on the dog and ensure that all dogs have the correct type of official form of
identification at all times.
To be corrected by: 18-August-2023

The information for six adult dogs is missing from APHIS form 7005 (Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand).
Additionally several dogs are missing their official identification number on the 7005 form. The facility is not keeping
record of disposition for dogs donated or rehomed at all. This information is required to be recorded on the APHIS Form
7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats). The dogs are crossed off the APHIS 7005 form without a date of sold,
removed, death or euthanized. Failure to document the information required on APHIS form 7005 and 7006 may interfere
with the ability of APHIS officials to identify animals and to trace their movements.
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the required information
concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of. The licensee must add the
information for the six dogs to APHIS form 7005 and ensure that all required documents are complete and contain all the
necessary information at all times. The licensee must also maintain disposition records that contain all the necessary
information for any dog that is sold, removed, donated, died or euthanized on an APHIS form 7006.

One puppy, Pug DOB 20-May-2023, is housed with a dog over 4 months old, French Bulldog DOB 13-December-2022,
that is not it's dam or foster dam. Housing puppies with adult dogs that are not their dam or foster dam may result in
injuries due to compatibility problems.
Puppies under 4 months of age or less may not be housed in the same primary enclosure with adult dogs other than their
dams or foster dams. The puppies mentioned above must be either housed with other puppies under 4 months of age or
less or their dam or foster dam.
To be corrected by: 15-August-2023

The facility is missing dates of administrations of vaccines and deworming treatments. Two litters of puppies containing a
total of 9 puppies did not have dates written down for their 2, 4 and 5 week preventative deworming treatments. Male
French Bulldog "Borris" is missing dates and names of medications given after a positive fecal test on 25-March-2023.
The dates of adult dog's Parvovirus and Distemper vaccines is also not recorded. Written medical records are necessary
for APHIS officials to determine that the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Dealers must keep medical records for dogs that include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the
dates of administration. The licensee must ensure that all vaccinations and deworming treatments provided to adult dogs
and puppies are documented in writing and available for APHIS inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee has changed the vaccination and deworming schedule for adults and puppies without consulting their 
attending veterinarian. The licensee states they no longer vaccinate for Hepatitis and Bordatella in adult dogs or vaccinate

Failure to follow the Program of Veterinary Care vaccination and deworming schedules approved by the attending

Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee 
must ensure that all dogs presenting abnormal conditions are evaluated and diagnosed by a veterinarian and that all 
vaccinations and deworming plans are approved by the attending veterinarian and followed in order to provide the dogs 
with adequate veterinary care. 
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Seven adult dogs do not have official identification placed on the dog. The licensee uses microchips placed under the skin 
as a form of official identification. The following dogs need a microchip: Gisella, Merlitta, Josie, Maggie, Moxie, Borris and 
French Bulldog born 13-December-2022. The French Bulldog is still being identified by its puppy cage card. Cage cards 
are not an acceptable form of official identification for dogs over 16 weeks of age. An acceptable form of official 
identification (listed below) is necessary for APHIS officials to positively identify animals for inspection and to properly

All live dogs over the age of 16 weeks shall be identified by an official tag affixed to a collar around the animal’s neck, by 
a legible tattoo marking approved by the Administrator, or by a microchip placed under the dog’s skin. The licensee must 
apply one of the forms of identification on the dog and ensure that all dogs have the correct type of official form of

identification at all times. 
To be corrected by: 18-August-2023 
2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The information for six adult dogs is missing from APHIS form 7005 (Record of Acquisition of Dogs and Cats on Hand). 
Additionally several dogs are missing their official identification number on the 7005 form. The facility is not keeping 
record of disposition for dogs donated or rehomed at all. This information is required to be recorded on the APHIS Form 
7006 (Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats). The dogs are crossed off the APHIS 7005 form without a date of sold, 
removed, death or euthanized. Failure to document the information required on APHIS form 7005 and 7006 may interfere 
with the ability of APHIS officials to identify animals and to trace their movements. 
Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the required information 
concerning each dog or cat purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of. The licensee must add the 
information for the six dogs to APHIS form 7005 and ensure that all required documents are complete and contain all the 
necessary information at all times. The licensee must also maintain disposition records that contain all the necessary 
information for any dog that is sold, removed, donated, died or euthanized on an APHIS form 7006. 
3.7(c) 
   
Compatible grouping. 
One puppy, Pug DOB 20-May-2023, is housed with a dog over 4 months old, French Bulldog DOB 13-December-2022, 
that is not it's dam or foster dam. Housing puppies with adult dogs that are not their dam or foster dam may result in 
injuries due to compatibility problems. 
Puppies under 4 months of age or less may not be housed in the same primary enclosure with adult dogs other than their 
dams or foster dams. The puppies mentioned above must be either housed with other puppies under 4 months of age or 
less or their dam or foster dam. 
To be corrected by: 15-August-2023 
3.13(b)(3)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is missing dates of administrations of vaccines and deworming treatments. Two litters of puppies containing a 
total of 9 puppies did not have dates written down for their 2, 4 and 5 week preventative deworming treatments. Male 
French Bulldog "Borris" is missing dates and names of medications given after a positive fecal test on 25-March-2023. 
The dates of adult dog's Parvovirus and Distemper vaccines is also not recorded. Written medical records are necessary 
for APHIS officials to determine that the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. 
Dealers must keep medical records for dogs that include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the 
dates of administration. The licensee must ensure that all vaccinations and deworming treatments provided to adult dogs 
and puppies are documented in writing and available for APHIS inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

n
